The Vishnu Purana describes a geographical location as Bharat in a shloka that reads, "Uttaram yat samudrasya, Himadreschaiva dakshinam, varsham tad Bharatam nama Bharati yatra santatih". This translates to "the country that lies to the north of the ocean and south of the snowy mountains is called Bharatam; there dwell the descendants of Bharata".

Two of the words we often use for our country are India and Bharat. The word India comes from the Indus, called Sindhu in Sanskrit. Find Iran and Greece in your Atlas. The Iranians and the Greeks who came through the Northwest about 2500 years ago and were familiar with the Indus, called it the Hindos or the Indos, and the land to the east of the river was called India. The name Bharata was used for a group of people who lived in the Northwest, and who are mentioned in the Rigveda, the earliest composition in Sanskrit (dated to about 3500 years ago). Later it was used for the country.

Unfortunately in India we are a divided lot. We look at everything in binaries. Either you have to love someone or hate them. Either you accept them completely or totally reject them. Two extreme positions. I'm not for such stances.

When we criticize public figures, especially political leaders remember that the individual as a person is not targeted but the role he/ she plays: whether the policies, laws, governance that the government advocates and practises are suitable or acceptable in the larger interests of the nation; these are questions that every individual must ask in a democracy instead of branding or labelling people as pro and anti.

Modi is the PM of a country representing a party that he belongs to. But as a PM he belongs to the nation and as a leader he can go wrong and make mistakes. No one is infallible. When one has absolute majority chances of going wrong are more. In a democracy it is the duty of the citizens to point out the flaws and the leadership must encourage that for the overall wellbeing of the nation.

So, if Dhruv comes across as someone who is perceived as тАШanti-modi' the fault perhaps lies elsewhere. May be there are more holes to be plugged; several areas that require attention for corrective measures. You may ask why isn't he talking about good things? I think he has. His video on NEP talks about the positive things in the policy too.

Also remember one need not spend much time on positive things that have happened because they have happened already. We should spend more time on correcting the wrongs, converting the negatives into positives. That's more important. Else the wrongs will negatively affect our growth and development.

If Dhruv is doing that isn't that a good thing? Isn't that what everyone wants? A better life for everyone? So instead of attaching importance to people or individuals let's start looking at issues and problems discussed.

The origin of the phrase "holy cow" as applied to Indians is a complex and debated issue. While the association of cows with holiness is deeply rooted in Hindu culture, the specific use of "holy cow" as a label for Indians is more likely recent.

Here's what we know:

Cow veneration in India: Hinduism reveres cows as sacred symbols of life and motherhood. They are protected and often considered auspicious. This practice dates back centuries and is well documented in ancient scriptures.

British observation and commentary: During their colonial rule in India, British observers and writers noted the veneration of cows by Indians. They often documented this practice in their writings, sometimes with a sense of amusement or condescension.

Evolution of the phrase: The exact origin of "holy cow" as a label for Indians is unclear. Some sources suggest it emerged in the late 19th or early 20th century, possibly as a way to mock or stereotype the Hindu belief system.

While it's possible that the British were the first to use the phrase in this context, there's no definitive evidence. It's more likely that the phrase arose from a combination of factors:

British observations: The British presence in India undoubtedly played a role in bringing the practice of cow veneration to wider attention. Their writings and commentary may have contributed to the association of "holy cow" with Indians.

Pre-existing stereotypes: Negative stereotypes about India and its culture likely existed before the British. The association of "holy cow" with Indians may have tapped into these pre-existing biases.

Evolution of slang: Phrases and slang terms evolve over time, acquiring new meanings and associations. It's possible that "holy cow" initially had a different meaning and eventually became associated with Indians due to various factors.

It's important to remember that labeling people with offensive terms is never acceptable, regardless of its origin. Even if the British were not the first to use "holy cow" in this way, it remains a problematic term that reinforces negative stereotypes and disrespects Hindu beliefs.

Instead of focusing on the precise origin of the phrase, we should strive for understanding and respect. Recognizing the diverse perspectives and historical context surrounding the use of "holy cow" is crucial for promoting cultural sensitivity and avoiding harmful generalizations.

The RSS trains Dalits and other тАЬbackward classesтАЭ as Hindu temple high priests, and otherwise work to remedy the social divisiveness of the caste system. They all eat together to break down caste taboos.

Tens of thousands of RSS members do volunteer relief work every time thereтАЩs a natural disaster in India. They set up first aid camps for victims, build shelters, help rebuild villages, and provide food, milk, potable water, clothes, and medical necessities. They adopt orphans, especially Muslims, and provide them education at least up to Higher Secondary level. They protected and helped members of the Sikh community during the 1984 anti-Sikh riots.

During the coronavirus lockdown, the RSS has been providing masks, soaps, and food to struggling poor people all over India, including to Muslims.

Whether or not you agree with their goal to form a Hindu Rashtra and strengthen the Hindu community, it is a fact that they do a lot of good work by which the nation of India and all of its citizens are benefited..

The term "India" was mistakenly applied to the Americas by Christopher Columbus, who believed he had reached the Indian subcontinent when he arrived in the Caribbean in 1492тАж

This is why Native Americans are sometimes referred to as "Indians," and the Caribbean islands are sometimes called the "West Indies." 

Columbus's error in navigation led to the misnaming of the indigenous peoples and the lands he encountered in the AmericasтАж

Dhruv bhai , what you said is correct but PM Modi has an intention to keep the name as bharat. Why?? The reason lies in the history of the country. Before foreigners started to invade the country, our country has only one name which is Bharat and this name was repeatedly used by our great divine people( like krishna and related people ). So this name is of great respect and this is why pm Modi wanted to change the name. But I know it is not correct to take such decisions suddenly and the name india had been used since a long time and its origin comes from Indus. But what my opinion is that although both names can be used interchangeably by anyone, the word Bharath should be given prior  importance to name the country than India because india doesn't have any big reason behind it's name but bharath has. For example when we speak any country related issues, we often use the word India than using bharath although we have the freedom of using any of these two words. In the same way if we often use the word bharath generally than india it would be nice rather than to change name completely. And it could be possible only by inculcating it into the minds of people of the upcoming generations( new borns presently) rather than people of present generations. So try to understand about our ancient epics rather than just trying to be like leftist and then speak on such issues. Because according to you ,any name has same importance. And you can understand why bharath has more importance than india only if you read our ancient scriptures, epics, vedas.

I think you have to set your mindset right in certain parameter of thinking. 

Allow me to delve deeper into the richness of ancient Bharat and how embracing this name can help us return to a path of prosperity and growth reminiscent of those golden eras. Moreover, I'll explain the profound meaning of the name "Bharat."

The Ancient Prosperity of Bharat:

In ancient times, Bharat was known as a land of incredible wealth, not just in material riches, but also in intellectual, spiritual, and cultural wealth. Our ancestors laid the foundations for numerous fields of knowledge, such as mathematics, astronomy, and medicine. The great universities of Nalanda and Takshashila attracted scholars from all over the world, making Bharat a global center for learning and wisdom.

Bharat was a hub of trade, with the Silk Route passing through its territories. This facilitated the exchange of goods, ideas, and cultures, contributing to the nation's prosperity. The Indus Valley Civilization, one of the world's oldest urban civilizations, showcases the architectural and engineering marvels of our ancestors.

The Meaning of Bharat:

The name "Bharat" carries profound significance:

Bha: Represents light, knowledge, and wisdom. It signifies the enlightenment our nation has offered to the world.

Ra: Stands for energy, movement, and dynamism. It symbolizes the spirit of progress and innovation.

Ta: Represents the essence of "tapa" or self-discipline and dedication. It signifies the commitment to excellence and self-improvement.

Bharat, therefore, embodies a nation that shines with knowledge, thrives through innovation, and upholds a strong commitment to self-improvement.

In conclusion, embracing the name Bharat is not merely a symbolic gesture but a call to action, an invitation to rediscover the treasures of our heritage, and a commitment to building a brighter future. By following the footsteps of our wise ancestors and nurturing our nation's strengths, we can once again become a beacon of prosperity, knowledge, and culture on the global stage.

Politicians are just trying to raise new conflict when religion conflicts stopped helping them. I feel ashamed even to debate on this or explain someone that why i dont want any name of our nation to be changed. Because we are Indians, we are Bhartiya, and we are Hindustani. that himanta bishwa that you were talking about..mostly nobody gives a shit about what he says in Assam..In Assam what ever he says..people call it "pralaaab bokise" which loosely translates to "He has gone mad and talking shit" He is called as "mama" (maternal uncle) is Assam. There is a history behind it..Lachit Borphukan..he was  a commander in chief in the battle of Soraighat (against Mughal) who killed his own uncle..the reason was that he was given the task of building an earthen wall for fortification which was assigned to his uncle .As a strategy that he devised for the battle next day, the wall was needed to to be to completed b4 sunrise next day ..but incomplete. In anger he drew his sword and killed his own uncle, without a second thought. He justified his act by saying " dekhot koi dangor mama nohoi" which translates to "country is more important than his uncle"...the idea of mama came from this..but i don't understand how come this became so positive. Himanta Biswa is known as mama is Assam. Everybody calls him mama..even he doesn't mind.

I am a Pakistani researcher who has delved into the history of the Indian subcontinent. With all due respect and a sincere intention not to cause any offense, I would like to express my understanding that the names India, Bharat, and Hindustan all refer to the same geographical region that is now divided into Hindustan, Pakistan, and Bangladesh. These names carry significant historical and cultural references.

For instance, the name India is derived from the Indus River, which also encompasses areas that are now called Pakistan and Bangladesh. Similarly, Bharat finds its origins in ancient Sanskrit texts, referring to the entire region, which implies that even Pakistan and Bangladesh are included in this historical context. So historically Pakistan and Bangladesh are also India and Bharat. However, it's important to note that these names originally referred to a united, undivided India or Bharat.

In light of the partition of this region into three distinct nations, including Pakistan and Bangladesh, the term Hindustan seems more appropriate as it reflects the unique identity of the remaining portion. 

Just want to mention that on an emotional and genetic level, I also consider myself the descendant of Indian/Bharti parents, as my forebears hailed from India/Bharat. So, I want to emphasize that I harbor no intention of causing any hurt or offense to anyone's feelings. To me, it is a reminder that a rose, regardless of the name it is given, will always carry its inherent beauty and fragrance. Peace!

Bharat ka matalab dekh mere bhai eternal everlasting

Sanatan" ya "eternal everlasting" ka matlab hai ki yeh kuch aisa hai jo hamesha ya anant samay tak sthiti mein rehta hai, kabhi ant nahi pata. Iske ant nahi hota, aur yeh sadiyon se chala aa raha hai. "Sanatan Dharma" ka arth hai ki yeh dharm hamesha se aur hamesha tak vidyaman hai, aur iska ant nahi hota. Ismein vyakti apne jivan aur moksha ke marg par chalne ke liye mool siddhanton ka palan karte hain, jo ki sadiyon se parampara me aaya hai.

Sanatan Dharma" Bharat mein Hindu dharm ko refer karne wala ek prachin shabda hai. Iska matlab hota hai "eternal" ya "everlasting religion." Is dharm mein mukhya rup se jivan ke mool siddhanton aur aacharanon par bal diya jata hai, jaise ki karma, dharma, punarjanm, moksha, aur yog. Yeh dharm Bharatiya sanskriti ka mahatvapurna hissa hai aur iska prachin itihas hai.

Well said!!! We should understand that India and Bharat, both are the names for the same country, neither of them being superior to each other. It's like we're creating a problem that doesn't exist !!!. India is a country with different cultures, religions, and even opinions. So, it's natural to have conflicting opinions in a nation. But it does not prove that one opinion is wrong and the other is right. It's not appropriate to stick on to a single name for the country because some of us are supporting it. Then what about others? It will be a complex problem then. We should not be muddling in these misunderstandings as we have greater and more relevant problems to deal with. WE SHOULD BE TOLERANT TO DIFFERENT VIEWS AND RESPECT THEM. IT'S WHAT DRIVES A COUNTRY, ESPECIALLY INDIA. Once again, well said Dhruv Rathee !!!

Use of Bharat symbolises actual independence-┬аIndia name for the newly independent nation did not signify the actual independence. Members who supported the name Bharat took Irish constitution example.┬аIrish Free State was one of the few countries in the modern world which changed its name on achieving freedom┬аand the fourth article of its Constitution refers to the change in the name of the land.

Name Bharat is befitting to our history and our culture-┬аVishnu Purana┬аand┬аBrahma┬аPurana┬аmentioned the geographical area as тАШBharatтАЩ. Seventh-century Chinese traveller┬аHiuen Tsang┬аhas also referred to the country as Bharat.

Emotional Attachment to the name Bharat-Bharat or Bharatvarsha forms an┬аincredibly strong emotional attachment┬аwhich is rooted in the Puranas. Country is witnessing┬атАШcivilizational reincarnationтАЩ.

Bharat connected to our National symbols-Indian National Anthem┬аis woven around Bharat. The National Flags and emblems are connected to Bharat.

Name of the country as India was foreign imposition-┬аClinging to the word тАШIndiaтАЩ shows that we are not ashamed of having this insulting word which has been imposed on us by alien rulers.

1. The first thing is that there is no historical text in India in which the word India is used for Bharat. Nor did any paraphrase mention India in his travelogues. 

2. Who gave permission to use the word "India" in the Constitution ? Was public opinion taken about this that time ? 

3. India that is Bharat !┬а Who forced such a sentence to be written in the first line of the constitution? According to you, the great freedom fighters of that time did this. But in my opinion it is not because freedom fighters like Mahatma Gandhi, Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel, were loved by the Swadeshi. 

4. Changing name due to change of language is a ridiculous thing. Can we call you pole Rathi ? Doesn't this seem strange to you ? Making a mistake does not mean that the mistake should be made again and again. Making quick amendments gives good results. 

5. If a language cannot write what it pronounces, then it is the fault of the script used in that language. Like you can't write рднрд╛рд░рдд in English.That means the English is not that rich as Hindi or Sanskrit. So the conclusion is, It is foolish to change one's name, just to make it easier to read in another language. 

6. Why are you so ashamed of calling yourself a Bharatiy ? Where you like to call yourself Indian. If there is any reason please tell. 

7. How can you say that our freedom fighters gave us independence by using the name "Indian"? BecauseThere was no slogan in the freedom struggle in which the word "India" was used. All these are issues after India became independent and Bapu left. 

8. Despite there already being so many political parties, how right is it to form one more party ? Uniting all the parties just to oppose one political party is seems against the Republic. After the people have won by voting, is it not a violation of the trust of the people to make a compromise between the political parties and form another party ? After the people have won the vote, the political parties have compromised and formed another party, isn't it like playing with people's trust? Also, what is the purpose of giving the name of the party to the name of the country? 

9. Why they were saying Indus is not the point. Why they could not say "Hindu", that is the point. There is no exact proof that Indus comes from the word Hindu. It may be two different words referring to the same place. Which may have different meanings. The reason why they called this place Indus is unclear. 

10. No one is spreading hatred. We just like the word Bharat. The name was India and will remain so. But we will definitely try to use the word Bharat as much as possible. 

11. Don't be angry. Just as naming a new political party "INDIA" is a part of politics, similarly protest the name INDIA is also a part of politics.

You gave a good perspective but I don't agree with that, simply because the name is not given to us by our kings or government 
Throughout history we have officially used the name bharat, I am talking about the Indian scriptures and Indian origin kings.

Hindustan or India was the name given to us by looters invaders or philosophers of other countries but not ours.

Even the native Americans are called Indians red Indians because it was thought 
And with the concepts of Indus river and all , even pakistan is India as per foreign philosophers as according to them Indians are people living beyond or around the Indus river.


Now as far as the constitution is concerned I know both India and Bharat are official names 
But the problem here is that we use English too much in our official business that's why 80-90% of the times we use the word India and not bharat.

INDIA AND BHARAT both are used to refer India let foreigners use the name INDIA but we can use Bharat for official business

The Hind name was came from  Adam's son who came from Srilanka in Hindustan. In Sanskrit isthan means place. Hindustan means Hind living place. As Adam came from heaven on earth at Srilanka. One of his son was migrated into India from ЁЯШЕSrilanka. So Hidustan means Hind's living place. Those who in it called Hindus. The original people of India was dravidians. Aran's came from central Asia into Hindustan. They also called as Hindus. All people who in Hindustan are Hindus irrespective of their caste, color & creed. Fight for name is irrational.

The British used the name "India" for the Indian subcontinent during their colonial rule from 1757-1947. The name comes from the Indus River, which marked the western boundary of British India. The British used the name "India" in legislation in the 19th and 20th centuries.
The name "India" has been used in Greek since Herodotus in the 4th century BC. The term appeared in Old English in the 9th century and reemerged in Modern English in the 17th century.
The name "Bharat" has a significant place in Indian culture. The name appears in Hindu epics like the Ramayana and Puranic literature. Both "Bharat" and "India" are mentioned in Article 1 of the Constitution. The meaning of India is "Land of Water", derived from Indus, which is nothing but a greek pronunciation of the word "Hindu". Originally, the land across the Sindhu river was known as Hind, which in return changed to Hindustan and India. The term Hindu isn't associated with religion, since it's the Persian version of the word "Sindhu". All these words come from Sindh river, which was first identified by Aryans and the famous Hindu book "Ramayan" was also written by Aryans almost 3000-5000 years ago, sitting on the bank of Indus river.

*What is Islam?* 
Islam is the name of the religion, or more properly the тАШway of lifeтАЩ, which God (Allah) has revealed and which was practiced by all of the Prophets and Messengers of God that He sent to mankind.  Islam specifically means being in the state of submission to God, worshipping Him Alone, and reverently accepting and obeying His Law. 

*Who are Muslims?*
The Arabic word тАЬMuslimтАЭ literally means тАЬsomeone who is in a state of Islam (submission to the will and law of God)тАЭ.  The message of Islam is meant for the entire world, and anyone who accepts this message becomes a Muslim.

*Who is Allah?*
Often one hears the Arabic word тАЬAllahтАЭ being used in discussions regarding Islam.  The word тАЬAllahтАЭ is simply the Arabic word for Almighty God, and is the same word used by Arabic speaking Christians and Jews.  As a matter of fact, the word Allah was in use far before the word God ever came into existence, since English is a relatively new language.  If one were to pick up an Arabic translation of the Bible, one would see the word тАЬAllahтАЭ being use where the word тАЬGodтАЭ is used in English.  For instance, Arabic speaking Christians say that Jesus is, according to their canon belief, the Son of Allah.  In addition, the Arabic word for Almighty God, тАЬAllahтАЭ, is quite similar to the word for God in other Semitic languages. 

*Who is Muhammad?*
The last and final prophet whom God sent to humanity was the Prophet Muhammad, may the mercy and blessings of God be upon him.

*What are the Teachings of Islam?*
The foundation of the Islamic faith is belief in absolute Monotheism (the Oneness of God).  This means to believe that there is only one Creator and Sustainer of everything in the Universe, and that nothing is divine or worthy of being worshipped except for Him.

*What is the Quran?*
The Quran is the final revelation of Allah to all of mankind, which was spoken by Allah the Exalted Himself and conveyed through the Arch-Angel Gabriel in Arabic to the Prophet Muhammad, in sound, word and meaning.

*What does Islam say about Jesus?*

The Islamic belief about Jesus demystifies for us who the real Jesus was.┬аJesus in Islam was an extraordinary individual, chosen by God as a Prophet and sent to the Jewish people.┬аHe never preached that he himself was God or the actual son of God.┬аHe was miraculously born without a father, and he performed many amazing miracles such as healing the blind and the lepers and raising the dead тАУ all by GodтАЩs permission.┬аMuslims believe that Jesus will return before the day of Judgement to bring justice and peace to the world.┬аThis Islamic belief about Jesus is similar to the belief of some of the early Christians.
